dt: {bc}to ruin or diminish the perfection or wholeness of {bc}{sx|spoil||}

dt.t: whose life has been {it}marred{/it} by problems with drugs
their relations were {it}marred{/it} by disgraceful conflicts
the race was {it}marred{/it} by a 23-car pileup

pt: {sc}injure{/sc} {sc}harm{/sc} {sc}hurt{/sc} {sc}damage{/sc} {sc}impair{/sc} {sc}mar{/sc} mean to affect injuriously. {sc}injure{/sc} implies the inflicting of anything detrimental to one's looks, comfort, health, or success.
{sc}harm{/sc} often stresses the inflicting of pain, suffering, or loss.
{sc}hurt{/sc} implies inflicting a wound to the body or to the feelings.
{sc}damage{/sc} suggests injury that lowers value or impairs usefulness.
{sc}impair{/sc} suggests a making less complete or efficient by deterioration or diminution.

pt.t: years of smoking had {it}impaired{/it} his health

pt: {sc}mar{/sc} applies to injury that spoils perfection (as of a surface) or causes disfigurement.

pt.t: the text is {it}marred{/it} by many typos

et: Middle English {it}marren{/it}, from Old English {it}mierran{/it} to obstruct, waste; akin to Old High German {it}merren{/it} to obstruct
shortdef: to ruin or diminish the perfection or wholeness of : spoil
to inflict serious bodily harm on

dt: city and port on the Atlantic south-southeast of Buenos Aires in eastern Argentina {it}population{/it} 593,300

shortdef: city and port on the Atlantic south-southeast of Buenos Aires in eastern Argentina population 593,300

dt: mountain range in southern Brazil along the Atlantic coast

shortdef: mountain range in southern Brazil along the Atlantic coast
